comments: For n > 1, the last digit cannot be 2, so a(n) has at least n+1 digits. The probability is big that none of [10^n/9]*20 + {1,3,7,9} is prime, in which case a(n) must have at least n+2 digits. This is the most frequent case. We can even conjecture that for all n > 1, a(n) equals [10^(n+1)/9]*20 + b with 1 <= b <= 9 and one of the (first) digits 2 replaced by 0 or 1. - _M. F. Hasler_, Feb 22 2016
